author: Supratim Adhikari
title: Apple slips behind Android in smartphone popularity stakes
text:
Android smartphones have pushed ahead of Apple’s iPhone in the popularity stakes in Australia and the impending release of the iPhone 6s is unlikely to alter the trend, according to data released by research firm Telsyte.
With an estimated 3.7 million smartphones sold in Australian in the first half of 2015, Telsyte research shows that sales of Android-based smartphones pulled ahead of the iPhone during the period, with a 54 per cent share compared to iPhone’s 41 per cent.
There’s little change in market share for Windows Phone-based devices, with a lack of new handsets and Microsoft’s transition away from the Nokia brand hampering uptake.
There’s also some good news for Sony, which has overtaken HTC to become the third largest smartphone vendor in Australia, behind Apple and Samsung.
Earlier this month, Sony unveiled three models of its flagship Xperia Z5 at the IFA 2015 event in Berlin.
The base model Z5 sports a 5.2-inch full HD display, with up to 32GB of flash storage and support for microSD cards of up to 200GB. Running on Android 5.1, it boasts an 8-core Qualcomm processor and a big 2,900 milliampere hour battery that Sony says can deliver battery life of up to 2 days.
According to Telsyte, the second half of 2015 should see 4.5 million smartphones sold, with pricing and brand still the key arbiters for buyers. However, there are doubts that Apple’s impending refresh to the iPhone 6 is likely to help it regain the top spot in Australia.
Despite the expected upgrades -- a 12 megapixel camera, Force Touch technology, and a front flash -- the tweaks are unlikely to be attractive enough to spark a big upgrade cycle. The Telsyte report also points to the increasing level of importance being placed on ‘lifestyle’ factors such as durability and resistance to the elements.
That trend is likely to benefit the secondary Android players in the market rather than Apple.
The data reinforces the primacy of smartphones as the favoured device for communications and portable computing and as the smartphone market enters maturity, the wearable devices trend still has some way to go.
According to the Telsyte data, despite the promotional hype surrounding smartwatches, only 205,000 units were sold in Australia in the first half of 2015.
Apple Watch is the market leader with a 64 per cent share in the first half of 2015, beating out both Samsung and LG. However, Apple’s competitors are catching up with Samsung’s Gear S2 a dramatically improved product and Motorola’s 42mm Moto 360 smartwatch coming to the market at an attractive price point.
Interestingly, Telsyte also found that some 10 per cent of smartwatch users stopped using their device altogether once the initial euphoria had evaporated.
Telsyte managing director Foad Fadaghi said that the lack of unique -- the so called 'killer' apps -- on smartwatches was still a big inhibitor to adoption.
“The Apple watch remains a luxury gadget, with its sales price typically more than twice the average of rival Android-compatible smartwatches,” he said.
“It is difficult to see mass market consumers paying as much as premium tablets or smartphones for wearable technology that does not have significant new or unique features.”
Despite the slow sales of smartwatches, smart wristbands such as those sold by Fitbit and Garmin continue to grow, up 30 per cent on H2 2014. Telsyte estimates that there are around 2 million smart wristband users in Australia.
